IMPORTANT NOTICE
A letter has been received by.
the Johns Hopkins student Council asking that the Hopkins student who witnessed an accident
at Charles and 29th streets, on
October 18, 1930, in which a
man was killed, get in touch
with Mr. WILLIAM R. SEAMANS at PLAZA 5328 at once.
Will the man who witnessed
the accident please co-operate
with the Student Council and
THE NEWS-LETTER by getting in touch with Mr. Seamans
immediately. This is urgent because an eye witness will tremendously aid the needy widow
and children of the victim of the
accident to collect damages.

FOUNDED 1897

S far back as I can remember,
Senior classes at Hopkins have
been voting H. L. Mencken
their favorite author. Which fact,
after being duly recorded in the
Hulabaloo in company with the statistics on sex irregularity, necking,
loafing, and choice of cigarette, he
was probably acquainted with. Not
being at all intimate with the learned
Mr. Mencken, I have never known
just what his reaction has been to
this perennial, and dubious, compliment. Perhaps he has been gratified
to know that a group of young men
who declare Chesterfields to be the
outstanding cigarette, also claim him
as their favorite writer. On the
other hand, and judging from what
his opinion of the average college
man seems to be, I am tempted to
lay a wager (a small one, of course)
that the estimable gentleman, thinking of his years of effort to develop a style of literature appealing to high intellects, has each year
thrown up his hands in despair and
cried, "Oh, what's the use!" while
honestly wishing he had gone in
for bookkeeping instead.

At Carleton College dormitory
parties are held with the men being
invited to them by the women. The
men who are invited to the various
dormitories are chosen from the
preference lists handed in by the
girls in the dormitories. Senior
girls are given first preference and
so on, in order of class ranking.
Besides dancing they have card
parties and special entertainment
features.

Affairs To Be Held Weekly At 1.30
P. M. In Levering Hall

Weekly informal musicales have
been introduced to the Hopkins by
a sponsoring committee which includes T. C. Ridout, Mrs. H. C.
MacJoton, Miss Mary Levin and
Miss Leonora MacIntyre. These
musicales will be held in order to
present local talent with an opportunity to display their accomplishments.
Hugo D. Weisgall, talented young
pianist, ushered in the series before
a large and appreciative audience of
students, secretaries, and members
of the faculty at 1 :30 p. m. last
Tuesday in Levering Hall. He
offered a diversified program of
short selections from a few of the
old masters.
The first selection was a Gavotte
by Handel, followed by a "Prelude
in G Minor" and "Invention in A
Minor," both by Bach. These selections were followed by "Rigaudon" by Remeau ;'Sonata" by Paradisi ; and "Suite" by Michelmann.
The last two numbers on the program were "Two Fugues" by Pachelbel, the first of which is an impression of a quiet, sedate ,young
girl, and the second an impression
of a young lady of opposite temperament—gay and carefree. These
pieces were combined by the composer. The lively girl is portrayed
both at the end and the beginning
of the selection, a fact which seems
to emphasize the composer's preference for the latter type.
Some of these numbers, although
written more that/ two centuries ago,
show a distinctly modern strain, not
only in time but also in arrangement.
All the selections were ably played
by Mr. Weisgall in spite of the poor
acoustics of the Hall in which he
played. These musicales will be
held once a week, on varying dates,
from 1 :30 until 2:00. It is hoped
that the attendance at the next
musicale will be as gratifying as at
the first.

Plans for a military ball were discussed at the meeting of the Officers' Club last Monday. A committee consisting of Ruark (chairman),
Fineman, Gordon and Wrightson,
was appointed to arrange for this
affair.
As in the past, all members of the
R. 0. T. C. unit including undergraduates and officers will be cordially invited.
This affair will probably be held
in Levering Hall in the latter part
of January or the early part of February.

"The Medieval Academy of

organization," declared the speaker

club, which, he says, was created
for "perpetuating the beloved memory of the only son of Sir William
and Lady Osler" by admitting into
the organization "students who bear
same resemblance to him in character and scholarship and who would
carry on his interests."
Among the guests were Sir D'Arcy Power, president of the Bibliological Society of England, and Dr.
Welch, of the Johns Hopkins Medical School.

Glass, Murback, Stegman
Lead J. H. U. Marksman
Individual contests conducted by
the Johns Hopkins University Rifle
Club during the week were won by
Glass, Murback and Stegman.
Contestants were divided into two
classes. Those who have taken part
in varsity matches this year were
separated from those who have not
participated in any important
matches. The participants fired
from four positions, prone, sitting,
kneeling and standing.
The prize for high score in the
first class was awarded to Glass,
who scored a total of 363 points.
Murbach was awarded the prize for
greatest improvement over previous
scores, gaining 27 points on his best
score.
Stegman won the high score
award in the second section by scoring a total of 352 points.
The J. H. U. team will compete
in marksmanship with the New
York Stock Exchange during this
week.

S far back as I can remember,
Senior classes at Hopkins have
been voting H. L. Mencken
their favorite author. Which fact,
after being duly recorded in the
Hulabaloo in company with the statistics on sex irregularity, necking,
loafing, and choice of cigarette, he
was probably acquainted with. Not
being at all intimate with the learned
Mr. Mencken, I have never known
just what his reaction has been to
this perennial, and dubious, compliment. Perhaps he has been gratified
to know that a group of young men
who declare Chesterfields to be the
outstanding cigarette, also claim him
as their favorite writer. On the
other hand, and judging from what
his opinion of the average college
man seems to be, I am tempted to
lay a wager (a small one, of course)
that the estimable gentleman, thinking of his years of effort to develop a style of literature appealing to high intellects, has each year
thrown up his hands in despair and
cried, "Oh, what's the use!" while
honestly wishing he had gone in
for bookkeeping instead.

At Carleton College dormitory
parties are held with the men being
invited to them by the women. The
men who are invited to the various
dormitories are chosen from the
preference lists handed in by the
girls in the dormitories. Senior
girls are given first preference and
so on, in order of class ranking.
Besides dancing they have card

Affairs To Be Held Weekly At 1.30
P. M. In Levering Hall

Weekly informal musicales have
been introduced to the Hopkins by
a sponsoring committee which includes T. C. Ridout, Mrs. H. C.
MacJoton, Miss Mary Levin and
Miss Leonora MacIntyre. These
musicales will be held in order to
present local talent with an opportunity to display their accomplishments.
Hugo D. Weisgall, talented young
pianist, ushered in the series before
a large and appreciative audience of
students, secretaries, and members
of the faculty at 1 :30 p. m. last
Tuesday in Levering Hall. He
offered a diversified program of
short selections from a few of the
old masters.
The first selection was a Gavotte
by Handel, followed by a "Prelude
in G Minor" and "Invention in A
Minor," both by Bach. These selections were followed by "Rigaudon" by Remeau ;'Sonata" by Paradisi ; and "Suite" by Michelmann.
The last two numbers on the program were "Two Fugues" by Pachelbel, the first of which is an impression of a quiet, sedate ,young
girl, and the second an impression
of a young lady of opposite temperament—gay and carefree. These
pieces were combined by the composer. The lively girl is portrayed
both at the end and the beginning
of the selection, a fact which seems
to emphasize the composer's preference for the latter type.
Some of these numbers, although
written more that/ two centuries ago,
show a distinctly modern strain, not
only in time but also in arrangement.
All the selections were ably played
by Mr. Weisgall in spite of the poor
acoustics of the Hall in which he
played. These musicales will be
held once a week, on varying dates,
from 1 :30 until 2:00. It is hoped
that the attendance at the next
musicale will be as gratifying as at
the first.

Plans for a military ball were discussed at the meeting of the Officers' Club last Monday. A committee consisting of Ruark (chairman),
Fineman, Gordon and Wrightson,
was appointed to arrange for this
affair.
As in the past, all members of the
R. 0. T. C. unit including undergraduates and officers will be cordially invited.
This affair will probably be held
in Levering Hall in the latter part
of January or the early part of February.

Medieval Academy Is
Topic of Address by Brown
(Continued from page 1, col. 3)

THE NORTH INN

"The Medieval Academy of
America is by no means a defunct
organization," declared the speaker
who discounted the general belief
that the Academy is in any way connected with Harvard University.
Dr. Henry Barton Jacobs, president of the Tudor and Stuart Club,
before introducing Mr. Brown, explained the purposes of the Hopkins
club, which, he says, was created
for "perpetuating the beloved memory of the only son of Sir William
and Lady Osler" by admitting into
the organization "students who bear
same resemblance to him in character and scholarship and who would
carry on his interests."
Among the guests were Sir D'Arcy Power, president of the Bibliological Society of England, and Dr.
Welch, of the Johns Hopkins Medical School.

Glass, Murback, Stegman
Lead J. H. U. Marksman
Individual contests conducted by
the Johns Hopkins University Rifle
Club during the week were won by
Glass, Murback and Stegman.
Contestants were divided into two
classes. Those who have taken part
in varsity matches this year were
separated from those who have not
participated in any important
matches. The participants fired
from four positions, prone, sitting,
kneeling and standing.
The prize for high score in the
first class was awarded to Glass,
who scored a total of 363 points.
Murbach was awarded the prize for
greatest improvement over previous
scores, gaining 27 points on his best
score.
Stegman won the high score
award in the second section by scoring a total of 352 points.
The J. H. U. team will compete
in marksmanship with the New
York Stock Exchange during this
week.

the League championship last year,
and this year has one of the most

Maryland State champion; Dooley
